header.title: The Scroll of Set - August 1993, Issue 129, Volume XIX-4
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Satanism (Temple of Set)

central_thesis: This issue of The Scroll of Set articulates the Temple of Set's core philosophy of individual self-transformation (Xeper) through disciplined Black Magical practices, integrating alchemical principles and rigorous self-analysis, while explicitly rejecting superstition and promoting a rational, self-aware engagement with both internal and external realities. It also addresses practical organizational conduct and critiques contemporary social and occult trends, reinforcing the Setian path as distinct from mainstream or 'old' occultism.

structure_content.summary: A poetic invocation emphasizing the eternal vigilance of silent 'Kas' and the enduring wisdom of the 'Scribes' of Amon, highlighting the quest for knowledge and self-remanifestation within the mysteries of the sages.
Administrative section acknowledging recent initiatory recognitions for members within the Temple of Set.

structure_content.chapter_title: [3] Setamorphic Alchemy: Life, Death, and Self-Initiation
structure_content.summary: This article outlines 'Setamorphic alchemy' as a system of self-initiation paralleling the alchemical process of the Philosopher's Stone. It defines VITRIOL as a path to finding the 'secret stone' within, equating it with the Setian concept of Xeper into higher states of being. The process involves transforming the 'uninitiated self' (First Matter) into 'pure gold' (consciousness/higher being) through elemental interactions and cycles of 'life, initiatory death, and Remanifestation'. The author sees Set as the higher intelligence to which the self aspires.

structure_content.chapter_title: [4] A War Cry to Defend the Existence of the Soul
structure_content.summary: A philosophical defense of the soul as a metaphysical entity beyond the physical brain, critiquing scientific materialism and cognitive psychology's limitations in explaining the totality of human being. It emphasizes the inward journey to explore subjective universes and the importance of 'nætic apprehension' of one's potential, linking it to 'Æon of Set Working II' as a process of change and self-discovery.

A collection of quotes from Carl Jung's 'Psychological Types' highlighting the importance of feeling and unconscious factors in understanding the world and making life decisions, as well as the 'incalculable' debt owed to imagination for creative work.

This article discusses the importance of individual will in Setian self-transformation, stating that the 'true magical being' (Setian) must rely on its own internal power rather than external 'Hierophants'. It emphasizes that true change comes from within and should not be externally dependent, aligning with the idea of Xeper as an internal, self-created reality.

structure_content.chapter_title: [7] A Walk in the Park with Set
structure_content.summary: A personal reflection on the experience of Set-consciousness, describing it as a deep, internal journey that clarifies the 'true image of ourselves'. It highlights the necessity of transforming contradiction into truth and balancing internal opposites through the faculties of self, bringing elements into synchronization for Xeper and Remanifestation.

This piece describes 'ÆS Working II' as a realization that true magic operates through sanity, clarity of thought, and deed, rather than superstitious evocations of personifications. It advocates for discarding ceremonial productions and black robes, emphasizing individual initiation, self-creation, and a contemporary view of the world, fostering unique individuals over a 'enlightened society'.

A detailed explanation of the 'Protocol' system within the Temple of Set, emphasizing respectful conduct not for superficial reasons, but to access wisdom from fellow Setians and to honor the Process. It distinguishes between profane and initiatory relationships, advocating for the transformation of more of one's life into initiatory practice and sharing central issues of initiation with a select few.

An analysis of operative magic, arguing that the critical factor is 'emotional clarity' rather than mere emotional intensity. It critiques traditional magical dogmas (including LaVey's) that prioritize strong emotion, suggesting that confused emotions hinder action. The article stresses precision, a 'coherent workable model of the world', and warns against the dangers of self-deception and impaired discrimination when inducing unclear emotional states.

A poetic piece evoking a sense of ancient, timeless existence, referencing 'dark fields of eternity' and the 'unseen waters of the abyss', concluding with a statement about a void seeking the void and undisturbed serenity.

This article explores magical names as powerful initiatory tools for self-differentiation and integration within the Temple of Set. It discusses how choosing a new name reflects inner change and helps solidify a 'new magical self'. The name serves as a 'creative word' of being, capable of evoking past transformation and invoking future becoming, and can be utilized as a mantra, power word, or talisman in ritual.

An announcement regarding the establishment and purpose of 'The Order of Anpu' within the Temple of Set, aimed at uncovering the 'true Black Magical dynamics of the Opener of the Way' within the Initiate's hidden self, leading to transformation and empowerment through clear vision.

A brief note on the re-publishing of works by Abraham Merritt, specifically mentioning 'The Metal Monster', 'The Moon Pool', 'Burn Witch Burn', 'Creep, Shadow!', 'Dwellers In The Mirage', 'The Face In The Abyss', and 'The Ship of Ishtar', and encouraging readers to request 'Seven Footprints To Satan'.
A short, poetic reflection on the timeless pursuit of knowledge, the transient nature of existence, and the eternal search for understanding beyond the veil of time and space.

A historical account of the 'Rite of the Headless One' (connected to Set-Typhon), its influence on the Golden Dawn and Aleister Crowley's 'Liber Samekh', and its significance for the 'Book of the Law'. It describes the ritual's purpose in self-identification with powerful figures and the casting away of restraints to become the god/Headless Daimon.

A critical analysis of 'old' occultism and its Christian-filtered baggage, advocating for a Setian approach that begins with a sound rational, logical, and scientific knowledge base. It asserts that true 'occultism' involves seeking, possessing, and applying 'secret knowledge' after exhausting conventional tools, using 'metaphysical philosophy' (GBM) as a tool for understanding and analysis, rather than engaging in 'ding-dong religions' that fill gaps with irrational beliefs.

Guidelines for submitting articles to The Scroll of Set, emphasizing the importance of diligent research, careful reflection, and a focus on generating interesting ideas rather than adherence to 'orthodoxy'. It highlights the Scroll as an 'active forum for the interplay of ideas' and a tool for learning and teaching.

An update on the process of digitizing and archiving past issues of The Scroll of Set, detailing the benefits (e.g., improved readability, elimination of filler) and drawbacks (e.g., loss of original layout and artwork) of the electronic format, and plans for future printed collections.

Notes on the Temple of Set's reading list, specifically addressing the 'Satanic Panic' literature of the 1980s. It recommends objective, scholarly works like Robert Hicks' 'In Pursuit of Satan' and Jeffrey S. Victor's 'Satanic Panic' to counter misinformation and contextualize the phenomenon.

A critique of the US Supreme Court's decision to uphold animal sacrifice in Santeria, expressing dismay at the cruelty involved. It calls for action against needless animal torture and killing, particularly in the context of animal experimentation, citing specific horrific examples and recommending PETA as a resource for cruelty-free products.

A first-person narrative recounting the author's disillusionment with animal research after participating in multiple surgeries on a shelter dog named Rodney. It highlights the moral and ethical considerations that outweigh perceived benefits, arguing against the abuse of 'lower animals' and concluding with a strong stance against animal experimentation.

key_concepts.definition: The process of individual self-creation and becoming, evolving into higher states of intelligent being through repeated experiences of life, initiatory death, and Remanifestation. It signifies coming into being as an intelligent 'substance' and creating a self-defined existence distinct from the natural universe.

Within Setamorphic Alchemy, it symbolizes the perfected self and the culmination of the alchemical process. It involves the transformation of 'raw physical material' (the uninitiated self or First Matter) into 'pure gold' (consciousness or higher being) through disciplined elemental interactions and cycles of initiatory death and rebirth.

The 'potential of substance and being', or the 'realm of creation' devoid of intrinsic characteristics or qualities until acted upon by conscious will. It represents the uninitiated self, holding the potential to become the 'Philosopher's Gold' through alchemical transformation.

An initiatory tool that serves as 'the creative word of our being expressing itself' or 'our I am'. It is chosen to facilitate self-differentiation, integration of personal facets, and the focused application of will for transformation. It can function as a mantra, power word, talisman, or be converted to runes for ritual use.

The quality of unambiguous and focused emotion, deemed crucial for effective operative magic and mundane actions. It is contrasted with mere emotional intensity or confused emotional states that hinder clear action and can lead to self-deception.

A foundational framework within the Temple of Set characterized by a rational, anti-superstitious approach to magic. It emphasizes individual self-creation, the defining of unique pathways between internal and external universes, and the conscious construction of one's own reality, moving beyond outdated rituals and beliefs.

A system of conduct and interaction within the Temple of Set that prioritizes respect for the Process and Initiates, not for social convention, but as a means to access wisdom and facilitate initiatory practice. It distinguishes between profane and initiatory relationships, advocating for discipline in personal and inter-Setian interactions.

Distinguished from 'old' or J/C-filtered occultism, Setian occultism begins with a solid rational, logical, and scientific knowledge base. It is defined as the process of seeking, possessing, and applying 'secret knowledge' (metaphysical philosophy or GBM) to comprehend and interact with existence after conventional tools have been exhausted.

practical_system.description: The document outlines a system of individual self-initiation and transformation within the Temple of Set, fundamentally based on 'Setamorphic Alchemy'. This system parallels the alchemical processes of the Philosopher's Stone, aiming to transform the 'uninitiated self' (First Matter) into a 'higher intelligence' or 'pure gold' (Xeper) through conscious will and disciplined practice. It emphasizes emotional clarity, rigorous self-analysis, and a rational, anti-superstitious approach to magic, where the individual is the primary locus of magical work and self-deification. This involves internalizing and externalizing one's 'I am' through specific rituals and tools.
tools: Will (the animating factor for First Matter, initiating self-realization and change)
Philosopher's Stone (symbol of the perfected, transformed self)
Wand (used to direct will upon the natural realm)
Cup/Graal (symbolic of the horizontal element, plane of infinity, containing the Elixir of Life)
Sword (representing the element of Intellect, used to divide opposites and rend veils of mystery)
Magical Names (used as mantras, power words, talismans, or runes for focusing will and manifesting change)
Emotional Clarity (a disciplined state of unambiguous and focused emotion, essential for effective operative magic)
Protocol (guidelines for internal social interaction within the Temple, fostering respect and access to wisdom)
Rational, logical, and scientific knowledge base (a prerequisite for Setian 'occultism', used to explain what can be before applying metaphysical tools)
Metaphysical Philosophy / Greater Black Magic (GBM) (the ultimate tool for understanding and analysis of phenomena beyond rational explanation, applied after exhausting scientific methods)
rituals: Setamorphic Alchemy (alchemical transformation of self through elemental interactions, mirroring cycles of life, initiatory death, and Remanifestation)
Repeated Xeper and Remanifestation (conscious striving towards higher states of being)
Invocation of the Headless One (a ritual for self-identification with divine power, involving specific names and incantations like AOTH ABRAOTH BASYM ISAK SABAOTH IAO)
Use of Magical Names in personal ritual chambers and public settings (declaring one's 'I am' to focus will and manifest transformation)
Æon of Set Working II (a broader framework for rejecting old paradigms and creating a new, self-defined reality)
Meditation and focused internal work (to achieve deep 'gut-realization' and connect with innermost Being)

relevant_quotes.text: VITRIOL, the Latin notaricon for Visita Interiora Terræ Rectificando Invenies Occultum Lapidem: “Visit the interior of the earth and by purifying you will find the secret stone." I find it most interesting that the vitriol formula states that one may find the secret stone, as opposed to making or creating it. If one is to indeed find the secret stone, to seek it out, it already exists!

Within the Temple of Set, we seek to Xeper into higher states of intelligent being through repeated Xeper and Remanifestation. I see Set as this higher intelligence to which I aspire, whether existing within my self, or externally beyond a star constellation or gate, it is my aspiring that matters.
The desire to Come into Being remains inert without the application of will. The process begins with will and self-realization: a birth.

Essentially the Left-Hand Path is a journey inward. Once more I experienced a deep “gut-realization” that we are all individuals, and ultimately we are alone in the midst of a mechanical, unfeeling, and uncaring universe.
This insight is also the core of Ipsissimus Aquino's Wewelsburg Working: “Strengthen, exalt and encourage the willful self, and you cannot avoid strengthening the natural instincts as well.”
I think it all turns to consciousness - it is the psyche with which we 'translate' the information provided by our senses.
The great decisions of human life have as a rule far more to do with the instincts and other mysterious unconscious factors than with conscious will and well-meaning reasonableness.
Any sufficiently advanced science is indistinguishable from magic, quoth Arthur C. Clarke.

I am the headless daimon with sight in my feet; I am the mighty one who possesses immortal fire; I am the truth that hateth the fact that unjust deeds are done in the world; I am the one who makes the lightning flash and the thunder roll, I am the one whose sweat is the heavy rain which falleth upon the world that it might be inseminated; I am the one whose mouth is utterly aflame; I am the one who begeteth and destroyeth: I am the Favor of the Æon: my name is a heart encircled by a serpent, come forth and follow.
The magical name is the creative word of our being expressing itself, it is our “I am”.

The Temple of Set is 180° away from this. To “do the Temple of Set right”, first you start with a sound rational, logical, and scientific knowledge base - both social and technical. You keep “religion” the hell out of this area [except in your analysis of social phenomena as a tool for popular control - see above].

After you have explained everything you can using rational, logical, and scientific tools, and see that there are some things “left over”, then you are at the point where you need to construct a tool to (a) make those things comprehensible to you and (b) perhaps apply some of them to your interaction with existence. Then and only then should you bring the Temple of Set into your life.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue of The Scroll of Set is highly relevant for understanding the philosophical and practical evolution of the Temple of Set in the early 1990s. It clarifies key concepts central to Setianism like Xeper, Setamorphic Alchemy, and the specific Setian definition of 'occultism,' which emphasizes a rational and anti-superstitious approach to Black Magic. The document provides direct insights into the internal discourse regarding self-initiation, magical practice, and the organization's deliberate rejection of traditional occult tropes. Furthermore, its engagement with broader socio-political issues like the Satanic Panic and animal rights demonstrates the Temple of Set's active stance in contemporary society.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Primarily members and Initiates (II° and above) of the Temple of Set, seeking in-depth guidance on self-transformation, magical practice, and adherence to organizational principles. It is also highly valuable for academic researchers and practitioners of Western Esotericism, modern Satanism, and new religious movements who wish to understand the theoretical underpinnings, practical mechanics, and socio-cultural context of the Temple of Set's unique approach to magic and philosophy.
